Una mala informaci√≥n telef√≥nica nos hizo perder la ma√±ana entre la consulta del especialista, en la cu√°l no nos atendieron sin cita en contra de lo que nos aseguraron por tel√©fono, y urgencias. Tras la inspecci√≥n en urgencias tendremos que volver otro d√≠a con la cita del especialista. Curiosamente el protocolo de atenci√≥n cambi√≥ el mismo d√≠a de nuestra visita y ya no nos atendieron directamente. Espero que el cambio de procedimiento sea para empeorar porque lo que es mejorar no lo est√°n haciendo.

Atenci√≥n y trato recibido por el personal: muy correcto.

Bad telephone information made us lose the morning between the specialist's consultation, in which they did not attend us without an appointment against what they assured us by phone, and emergencies. After the emergency inspection we will have to return another day with the specialist's appointment. Curiously, the care protocol changed the same day as our visit and we were no longer directly seen. I hope that the change in procedure is to make matters worse because what is improving is not being done.

Attention and treatment received by the staff: very correct.
Condition of the facilities: correct
Toilets: highly upgradeable

But we leave very happy.

Hem tingut el nostre fill a l'hospital, va n√©ixer el 30 de gener de 2018. Les llevadores que ens van atendre van ser molt simp√†tiques i agradables, explicant-nos en tot moment qu√® passava i qu√® farien.

The infermeras and doctors very well. But I find the menu very expensive ‚Ç¨ 16.95 and the sandwiches and etc. I found it expensive. After the bookstore or kiosk I found it very poor in magazines and details that were not there. To watch TV you have to pay ‚Ç¨ 6.50 one day .
Otherwise, all good.

La atenci√≥n de las enfermeras y auxiliares de la cuarta planta es penosa.Excepto Samanta que si es toda una profesional.Y una tal Mar√≠a que preferible trabajase en otra cosa.Parking car√≠simo,5 horas es 20 euro,cafeter√≠a egualLista de espera largu√≠sima.Todos va por lo mismo dinero....que penoso verlo de esta manera

No me gusta el tiempo, mejor dicho horas, que tardan en darte la habitaci√≥n ya teni√©ndola asignada. El trato en la habitaci√≥n excelente.

I do not like the time, or rather hours, that it takes to give you the room already having it assigned. The treatment in the room excellent.

Mal√≠sima organizaci√≥n en general. Fuimos de urgencias por dolor abdominal y dejaron a mi novio ingresado. Las urgencias saturadas de gente ingresada, no ten√≠an habitaciones disponibles, as√≠ que colocaron a los enfermos en lo que ellos llamaban un "hospital de d√≠a", una gran habitaci√≥n con varias camas separadas por cortinas. Nos dijeron que le pasar√≠an a la habitaci√≥n y estuvo all√≠ dos noches. Falta de personal, falta de comunicaci√≥n entre ellos, retrasos en las pruebas que le ten√≠an que realizar, no dispon√≠an ni de botellas de agua, necesaria para la medicaci√≥n que tenia que tomar para la prueba que le ten√≠an que hacer. 5 d√≠as ingresado inicialmente por un posible crhon y finalmente no le dieron un diagnostico claro, porque no sab√≠an seguro que tenia, y a d√≠a de hoy seguimos con pruebas... en fin,  muy mala experiencia y no ha sido la primera que nos encontramos en este hospital. La administraci√≥n tambi√©n es p√©sima. L√°stima que no haya otro hospital privado por la zona, en el que hayan profesionales y te atiendan correctamente.

(Translated by Google)
Bad organization in general. We went to the emergency room for abdominal pain and my boyfriend was admitted. The ERs, saturated with hospitalized people, had no rooms available, so they placed the sick in what they called a "day hospital", a large room with several beds separated by curtains. We were told they would transfer him to his room and he was there for two nights. Lack of personnel, lack of communication between them, delays in the tests they had to carry out, they did not even have bottles of water, necessary for the medication they had to take for the test they had to do. 5 days initially admitted for a possible crime and finally they did not give him a clear diagnosis, because they did not know for sure that he had, and today we continue with tests ... well, very bad experience and it was not the first that we found in this hospital. Management is also lousy. Too bad there is no other private hospital in the area, where they have professionals and take care of you correctly.

Venimos de urgencias a las 20:00 por dolor estomacal. No pueden hacer ecograf√≠a porque el ec√≥grafo trabaja hasta las 17:00. Esto es un Hospital?

fatal

fatal

In addition, they are almost always very agile and when it could not be, because there were really many people waiting. I have also gone in an emergency occasion and also very well

bueno

(Translated by Google) I had been suffering from kidney stones for more than half a year and had already switched hospital twice before finally arriving at Quiron.

When I first called Maria from patient counseling and said that I had been in pain for months, she immediately started working for me.

We kept in touch via Whatsapp and she arranged a place with the doctor and for the crushing of my kidney stone within 2 days.

During the whole process, every specialist explained what was going to happen and I was looked after very well.

We have been living in Spain for several years where this is the first time that I have seen an organization act so professionally and proactively

Quiron M√°laga understands that the patient comes first and that is very special here in Spain!

Via Whatsapp hielden we contact en regelde zij een plaats bij de dokter en voor het vergruizen van mijn niersteen binnen 2 dagen.

My father was admitted to this hospital 9 months ago and I flew in to be with him. Having worked in the NHS for 22 years I found the manual handling with patients was like a throw back the NHS in the early 90's. My father was man handled by the biggest nurse and placed on chair or bed as required. There should have been hoists or standaids. The shower room was badly laid out with no rails to assist patients on/off toilets and the bidet was placed directly in front of the toilet which meant walking aids could not be used effectively. The shower was not wet floor hence a wheeled shower chair could not be pushed in to place if required. There were no commodes or shower chairs available. The nursing and medical staff failed to treat my fathers severe constipation/ impaction until we pointed this out.  Certainly a hospital to avoid

Firstly I commend Inma who performed my MRIs - she was extremely friendly and pleasant and calmed my nerves for the procedure. She and an orthopedic doc I was wrongly sent to get a 5 star review, but not the rest. The neuro doesn't even deserve 1 star.

How it all started was very bad. I visited the emergency room for increased pain with my postherpetic neuralgia and numbness in my backside and pins and needles in my feet.. The resident doctor who saw me had apparently not heard of "neuralgia postherpetica" even though I said that in Spanish, and sent me to an orthopedic surgeon for my "back pain.".

The ortho was very nice and professional, and got me an appointment with a neurologist the next day. The male neurologist was so young that even at 65, he could have been my grandson. LOL. He merely started me on pain control for the PHN, including the dreaded gabapentin. I took the drug for one month (low dosage) but it did nothing. When I saw him again, he prescribed pain patches, proudly showed me the results of my MRIs, but did not address the numbness in my rear or the problem with my feet. He also didn't advise me to taper off the gabapentin, which is highly recommended on all major medical sites, including the NHS website..

Two days later I suffered withdrawal symptoms so bad, I even considered ending it all. When I contacted his secretary, I was told the doctor said that I wouldn't get withdrawal symptoms, because I didn't have epilepsy! Gabapentin is a highly addictive drug for God's sake! I read in the US News that the drug is now a  part of the major opioid crisis there, as the drug is often found in drug addicts blood along with heroin and fentanyl!

It is difficult to get appointments with neurologists elsewhere so seeing another neurologist at Quironsalud Marbella on Monday who will hopefully address the numbness in my backside and treat the symptoms correctly. I had also had a painful EKG along with the MRIs almost a month ago, but have had no results for that - if there is a nerve problem in my lower back/backside area, it would probably show up there. However, even when I log into their website, there are no results shown.

Meanwhile my co-payments with Sanitas keep on adding up, at 24 euros for the "emergency room doctor" and 12 euros per procedure and doctor visit, never mind the three sets of prescriptions, which I have to pay for, so far.

Nombre del establecimiento: Hospital Universitario Ruber Juan Bravo (C/Juan Bravo, 49)
content:
(Translated by Google) Hello, I want to tell you that my mother and I had a bad time yesterday: My mother had yesterday 15/02/2018 at 6:45 p.m. first consultation - appointment in Cardiology in Juan Bravo, 49 - pl. 8. As it was the first time that we went to the hospital by recommendation we did not know where to enter and we entered through Admission-ground floor, there was a queue of 3 people and I said to the reception lady "Excuse me, we have an appointment right now in Cardiology Where do we have to go? " He replies very sulkily "Wait, can't you see I'm attending?" Imagining that we would have to prove ourselves right there because we get in line, and at 7:05 pm when it is our turn he says "You have to go outside and on the left", we could not believe that he made us take the consultation and wait for nothing when we I could have said it from the beginning, the same thing happened with another young lady who was going to Gynecology. I told him I was going to make a complaint and he started shouting behind us and in front of other patients "Put it on, put it on, put it on !!"
When we finally got to the 8th floor in Cardiology Admission at 7:10 p.m., after having told them what happened, he told us not to worry, that there are two people in front because we are late and that's it. Well, at 19:45 they hardly tell my mother to go to the room to undress from the middle up to do an electrocardiogram (I imagine that is what they do, we wait for the doctor in the first consultation), they let her wait half Naked hour (it happened to another woman who also came out and complained) while the receptionists were talking (there were many older people waiting and worrying about the delays). At around 8:00 p.m. I go to the Admission desk and ask what is happening, that we had been told that we had two people in front and more have entered and we do not even have a ticket with a number to call us as everyone has, she says no the printer printed it but all the people who had come after us had it, they tell me that only one more person will pass and that's it. At 8:30 pm I speak to them again, they tell me that it was our fault, that we had delayed and that they are not going to let other patients delay because of us; I explain to you again what happened to us in Admission and I tell you that at least you could have told us from the beginning, not lying to us that one more person is passing and that's it (my mother is hypertensive and had high blood pressure) and they I explain that they are not right, because if at 6:45 p.m. when my mom is not for her appointment the doctor will pick up the next person (who will be ahead of her time, right?) and when my mom is there she will have picked up the appointment of a person who It is over, nobody is late. I ask where I can make a complaint and while we were waiting (it was already 8.45pm) a doctor came out, very on edge, asking the receptionist: "Who is it?" She indicated that we, we got up thinking that we went to his office and shouts from the other end "No no, do not take the coats that will not be attended to yet". I explain the situation to him and he says "It is what it is", I ask again where you can claim all this bad time that we were put through and make a sign with the men like you don't know, turn around and leave. We understood with your attitude that we will never be attended to; I tell the receptionist that we are going and she says okay, she does not mention anything about the EKG, or apologies, or anything.
When we got off I went back to Admission seeing the same young lady from before, I asked her about the complaint and she told me that in "Patient Care", I went there and the door was closed, I went back to her counter and told her, he laughs and says "there is, they close at 8pm ..." I go down to the ER and just there they give me a complaint form.
We are of Romanian nationality, nobody has ever treated us like this, I will think that it can be discrimination, racism "even.
We will put a claim in Consumption too, it is not normal that we have to ask permission to leave work to get to the appointment.

Imaginando que tendr√≠amos que acreditarnos ah√≠ mismo pues nos ponemos a la cola, y a las 19.05h cuando nos toca me dice "Ten√©is que salir fuera y a mano izquierda", no nos pod√≠amos creer que nos hizo tardar a la consulta y esperar para nada cuando nos lo podr√≠a haber dicho desde un principio, lo mismo pas√≥ con otra se√±orita que iba a Ginecolog√≠a. Cuando llegamos a la planta 8 por fin en Admisi√≥n Cardiolog√≠a a las 19.10h, despu√©s de haberles contado que pas√≥ nos dijo que no nos preocup√°ramos, que hay dos personas delante porque nos retrasamos y ya. Bueno, a las 19.45h apenas le dicen a mi madre que vaya a la sala a desnudarse de la mitad para arriba para hacerle un electrocardiograma (imagino que es lo que hacen, nosotras esperamos para el medico en primera consulta), la dejan esperar media hora desnuda (le pas√≥ a otra mujer tambi√©n que sali√≥ y se quejo) mientras las recepcionistas estaban conversando (hab√≠a mucha gente mayor esperando e inquiet√°ndose por los retrasos). Sobre las 20h me voy al mostrador de Admisi√≥n y pregunto que esta pasando, que nos hab√≠an dicho que ten√≠amos dos personas delante y han entrado m√°s y nosotras no tenemos siquiera un ticket con numero para nos llame como tiene todo el mundo, me dice que no lo imprimi√≥ la impresora pero toda la gente que hab√≠a venido detr√°s de nosotras lo ten√≠an, me dicen que solo pasar√° un persona mas y ya est√°. A las 20.30h hablo de nuevo con ellas, me dicen que era nuestra culpa, que nos hab√≠amos retrasado y que no van a dejar retrasarse a otros pacientes por nuestra culpa; les vuelvo a explicar lo que nos ¬¥pas√≥ abajo en Admisi√≥n y les digo que por lo menos nos podr√≠an hab√©rnoslo dicho desde un principio, no minti√©ndonos que pasa una persona m√°s y ya esta (mi madre es hipertensiva y ten√≠a la tensi√≥n elevada) y les explico que no tienen raz√≥n, porque si a las 18.45h cuando mi mam√° no est√° para su cita el doctor coger√° a la siguiente persona (que se adelantar√° a su hora no?) y cuando mi mama est√© habr√° cogido la cita de una persona que ya pas√≥, nadie se retrasa. Pregunto donde puedo poner una queja y mientras est√°bamos esperando (ya eran las 20.45h) sale un doctor,  muy borde, preguntando a la recepcionista: "Quien es?¬ø" Ella le indica que nosotras, nos levantamos pensando que acudimos a su oficina y grita desde la otra punta "No no, no se cojan los abrigos que todav√≠a no se les atender√°". Le explico la situaci√≥n y nos dice "Es lo que hay", pregunto de nuevo donde se puede reclamar todo este mal rato que nos hicieron pasar y hace una se√±al con los hombre como que no sabe, se da la vuelta y se va. Entendimos con su actitud que no se nos va a atender nunca; le comento a la recepcionista que vamos y dice que vale, no nos menciona nada del Electrocardiograma, ni disculpas, ni nada.
Cuando bajamos me fui de nuevo a Admisi√≥n viendo a la misma se√±orita de antes, la pregunto por la queja y me dice que en "Atenci√≥n al Paciente" , me dirijo ah√≠ y la puerta estaba cerrada, vuelvo a su mostrador y se lo cuento, se pone a re√≠r y me dice "hay, es que cierran a las 20h..." Pondremos una reclamaci√≥n en Consumo tambi√©n, no es normal que tengamos que pedir permiso para salir del trabajo para llegar a la cita.

La ginec√≥loga que sabia del tema estaba en su casa y entre gritos de la que le atend√≠a y un mont√≥n de enfermeros que empezaron a aparecer me llevaron a la sala de operaciones. Aunque recuerdo que en el camino se confundieron y ante me metieron en otra. Ya poco mas recuerdo.
Cuando despert√©, me di cuenta al 3dia aun en la Uci que me dol√≠a la pierna izquierda y es que me la hab√≠an quemado con el bistur√≠ el√©ctrico en el quir√≥fano. Ten√≠a y 6 pompas grandes desde la mitad del muslo a la parte baja de la rodilla.
Cualquier m√©dico con un poco de experiencia apagar√≠a el bistur√≠ o no lo dejaria en la camilla. Pero es que todo el mundo era muy muy joven.
Ta en planta era un poco desastre porque cafa nada cambiaban de enfermera y no leian los informes de las anteriores , por ej: tuve ileo paral√≠tico postquir√∫gico y una enfermera me trajo comida cuando no pod√≠a comer y eso me provoc√≥ estar 4 dias mas con las sondas. Tambi√©n me dio reacci√≥n el hierro y venieron dos enfermeras que le daban al bot√≥n para administrarmelo.
Todo √©sto est√°s en la camilla sin poder hablar con las sondas. Super d√©bil con un beb√© que no puedes casi ni mirar porque no tienes ni fuerza para girar la cabeza ..
En fin, el final fue feliz porque me recuper√© y no fallec√≠ ( a mi marido se lo pusieron muy negro). Todos estamos bien.

My experience in that hospital was a complete disaster.
Gynecology.
I went to a review of the "straps". I had no contractions but I was dilated and they told me to stay and give birth. They broke my bag and forced me to put on oxytocin "these are hospital rules" "otherwise this will last a long time" said the matron, although I did not want to. It was 9 when everything started. They practiced the Kristeller maneuvers on me. And in three hours (I am a first-time mother) my son was born, so that the placenta came out, Kristeller maneuvered me again and it hurt. As a consequence I had a uterine rupture. To say that I had never undergone surgery for anything and that my uterus until that moment was in perfect condition. The gynecologist who knew about the subject was at her home and amid shouts from the woman who was treating her and a lot of nurses who started showing up, took me to the operating room. Although I remember that on the way they got confused and before they put me in another. I remember little more.
When I woke up, I noticed that even in the ICU, my left leg was aching and that it had been burned with the electric scalpel in the operating room. He had 6 large bubbles from mid-thigh to lower knee.
Any doctor with a little experience would either turn off the scalpel or not leave it on the table. But is that everyone was very very young.
Ta in the plant was a bit of a disaster because nothing changed the nurse and they did not read the reports of the previous ones, for example: I had post-surgical paralytic ileus and a nurse brought me food when I could not eat and that caused me to spend 4 more days with the probes . The iron also gave me a reaction and two nurses came and gave the button to administer it.
All this you are on the stretcher without being able to speak with the probes. Super weak with a baby that you can hardly even look at because you have no strength to turn your head.
Anyway, the end was happy because I recovered and did not die (my husband was made very black). We are all fine.

Our experience was horrible. We were traveling in Barcelona; my husband got sick with a strong pain in his belly and on his back. We decided to go to this hospital because it was the closest, and we have private insurance. We entered it at 11 in the morning and left at 8 in the evening. There was no one in the emergency area and despite this they take an hour to assist us. They move us to another room where they put painkillers and all the staff of that department talking loudly about their private lives, their rent, purchases, work shifts, unbearable noise there was for some sick people. The doctor tells him that he was attending to him (two hours after seeing him) that they do a TAC to see what he has, since they do not know. They perform this test and at no time no one from reception, management or whoever is in charge of this process tells us that we have to pay for this test or that we call our insurance to ask for authorization.
After 7 o'clock in the afternoon the "doctor" tells us in a waiting room full of companions in a loud voice, "you need an urgent admission and operation because you have two kidney stones that are eating that organ". We decided to take the first flight, not to enter this hospital since it was very far from our families and to return to our house.
Once we land, we go to the hospital that corresponds to us, we do X-ray and ultrasound. Two doctors tell us that there they saw that there is no stone to eat a kidney and much less that the size they need intervention. They sent him a medication and expelled them the next day at home.
We wonder what they play in this "hospital". To intervene people without having to go through it, just to fill your pocket? To perform unnecessary tests irradiating my partner that are not useful for their diagnosis because they knew that our insurance did not cover us and we did not?
An embarrassment of treatment, lack of respect, lack of privacy, noise, the fright they gave us, the expenses that caused us without reason because we did not have to go back, since we did not need intervention ...
An endless number of negative aspects to highlight in our experience at the "Hospital El Pilar". Not recommended at all because they DEDICATE TO PLAY WITH THE HEALTH OF THE SICK.

I went and released everything proud and nervous, in the hallway upstairs: "In my 50 years of experience, a person in his mother's situation has very little life left."
You could guess her wish (to take me directly to the cemetery).
Imagine the skills of an actor I had to take out when, when I returned to the room, my mother was waiting for me to ask me: What did the doctor want?
Months later, my mother was admitted again, but in the Moncloa hospital, and thanks to Dr. Vanessa Sendin, I learned that not all doctors are the same.

He answered me after looking at him that he was only going to do one because they were not both, that he was late and the day was late because I had arrived 10 minutes late and that it could not be, that he would make an appointment for another day.

The next day I was before the time it was my turn and I had to wait 20 min for them to call me and everything was fine during the MRI ... until when there was only one sequence left to finish the study, the machine aborted the sequence because it was very hot in the room, so I had to wait an hour and a half. Summary: that the machine breaks, well it is something that can happen, but that a lightning technician does not want to do his job because it took him 20 min. (when I had to wait for the patient in front of me to come out) AMAZING.

The Gravis Miast√©nia that I was diagnosed with last July, this time took me to the ICU for 39 days (Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure), 18 of which were connected to a mechanical respirator. As a consequence, pneumonia and lung infection developed, and septic shock occurred. After the intubation period and the difficulty in breathing persisted, a tracheostomy was performed. Despite my critical condition, I was aware that
I was in good hands that would take me to a safe harbor. In the hands of a magnificent team with experience, a lot of experience, security and full command in their specialty, and with a high resolution power to successfully overcome all the complications that arose in my body. With a human quality difficult to match and impossible to beat. All this under the direction of Dr. Rosa Corcuera. Thanks to all their efforts they managed to not only be able to breathe again but also to smile. A team subjected to a lot of pressure, in most of the times, undervalued in some others and little recognized for its professional successes.

For everything that happened, receive my eternal gratitude.
A hug

Dr. la Torre's team operated on my wife on her spine and I can assure you that the only thing that worries these gentlemen are the figures, you have to make money whatever. It seems incredible that they do not realize that they work with people and that now my wife, for not having dedicated the necessary time to the intervention and leaving her badly operated, will now have to undergo another reoperation with many more risks. The treatment after the operation becomes degrading, "this client can no longer be squeezed" with which you happen to be a nuisance that steals their time. We have subsequently learned of a large number of the same cases. I said, flee from this Dr. who only knows how to take advantage of the publicity that he gave to D. Juan CArlos.

I'm surprised to see so many negative reviews here. My experience was definitely 5 stars. I went there this morning with my daughter who had dislocated her elbow. From the minute we arrived everyone was so helpful and so friendly. My daughter is only 3 and everyone made her feel safe and comfortable. From the receptionist Becky to the first doctor we met to the Radiographer to the orthopaedic staff, all were very professional and efficient. We are on family holiday and were quite upset that our daughter was in pain. We were in and out of this hospital in 2 hours with my daughter well and happy. Thank you so much for taking care of her. We can now continue to enjoy our holiday. And I would recommend you to anyone needing care in Tenerife while on holiday.

If your child becomes seriously unwell whilst holidaying in Tenerife please do not go to this hospital, please go to the Candelaria hospital in Santa Cruz. The Candelaria is a public hospital with a peadiatric department. Our son was seriously ill and was not treated well or given appropriate care at the Quiron hospital. The staff were rude, and very rough with our baby and dismissive of our concerns. We asked to be transferred and received much better care at the Candelaria. Extremely disappointing for a private hospital where you have to pay before any care is provided.

My mum was saved at Teknon 20 years ago when she arrived almost dead by a sepsis caused by a kidney stone.. she, my father who later had to go a few times since he had some ictus and later cancer was always super well attended. No one is perfect and I do feel though, that the change from Teknon to Quir√≥n Salut, has left some trails of bad organising and communication with stuff etc. Also, another fault of our systems of private insurances ( my family is from MEDI-FIACT) but there a too many out there, they all go in different proportions of contracting of services for which us, clients not of Teknon but of Medifiact for example, do not really know in which terms of preference for the budget and investment our company has rights to more or to less care, etc. One thing I have noticed in the comments which I find extremely irritating is the colonial "empire" mentality of the English folk here pretending we have all to speak English for the sake of their supremacy. If you go to a country you learn the few words needed or take a dictionary with you. I live in UK and even at the Home Office no one ever spoke any alternative language as of course the colonialist attitude is all and everywhere. To the point that English tourist have complained there are too many Spaniards in an hotel in Benidorm. It's shameful anyone criticises the education of a country who speaks its various languages. It's first, been el Catal√°n, and then, shared with the rest of the provinces, been el Castellano. I would not dare to go to Scotland or London for that matter and ask the hospital to know Catal√°n or Spanish. Before my planned hopital treatment I read the numerous reviews about the Quiron Hospital based in Marbella.

Reviews were very mixed yet it was the hospital recommended by my health insurance company for my eye cataract procedure.

Having now had the procedure two days ago,  I can in fact highly recommend the hospital staff, nurses and doctors who treated me with utmost courtesy.

They provided an excellent professional and highly competent technical service; from the administrative staff to the technical excellence of the opthalmic surgeon who seamlessly completed my cataract procedure.

Therefore I have no hesitation in recommending this hospital for anybody requiring a similar procedure.

The surgical procedure was carried out by external opthamologist Dra. Gloria Carretero and her surgical support team.

Frederick Millan. (UK).

Admitted last night after blacking out, and falling down on the roadside concrete. Alcohol WAS NOT involved. Saw admission doctor in the emergency department who did a general medical examination" - heartbeat, poke your tongue out etc- and sent for a neck x-ray, and CAT scan of brain. I had fallen twice, had a thumping headache (which l am not prone to) and suffered a huge raspberry coloured haematoma on the back of my skull. He wasn't interested. Next thing l'm told in a very loud voice in front of a room full of people having solutions dripped into their arms that this doctor wants to admit me. No particular reason was given so when l said l would actually prefer to go home the doctor's voice rose even more as he shouted l would have to sign a release form absolving the hospital etc. There was no privacy, this exchange took place in a public treatment room & the corridor outside.
I decided to stay the night as l still had the headache & no real medical explanation of why l might have fallen. Upstairs l went to a room. Someone brought a tray of very ordinary luke warm food and a nurse took my bood pressure and inserted an incredibly slow saline drip into the cathetar the emergency nurse had installed.
Since then no one has entered my room except a breakfast lady.
I understood l was being admitted to be monitored. Not a soul apart from the breakfast lady has been near me for 12 hours. Certainly there has not been any care, monitoring or communication. And ... the noise in the area outside my room has been unnecessarily loud since 5am - banging of containers, doors slamming, metal dropping, staff shouting, laughing and general merriment.
So, no monitoring, no explanations, no care, and despite the hospital's promise to investigate previous grieviances on this site l feel this was a total money-grab by Quiron.

I went to this clinic because of the great appreciation that the medical team at Doctoralia treasured. Tell you that it took 5 or 6 attempts to publish my opinion on that page about the medical team that operated on me and I think there will be no way.
As you have asked me from patient care to tell you about it, I have written to you but I see that you have not answered me. The same thing is that the mail does not reach you so I answer you here. I tell you my experience in case you can improve something. My opinion is based on my experience in a colon resection performed by the J.C.M.D team using laparoscopy. Intervention whose duration is normally estimated at approximately 2 hours (sometimes they extend to 4 hours) and which lasted for about 7 hours and 35 minutes and which, in addition, had to be repeated on two other occasions in about 20 days. From the first operation (without going into more details), the result was an ischemia, which I do not know if it could have been detected in time before, with the result of gangrene and the total amputation of the ascending intestine and part of the transverse.

I would have liked more attention when I lost consciousness after the operation (a doctor had come before and they had done at least one electrocardiogram), when I started to vomit so much (I vomited liters and liters. From our point of view the belly was especially dilated As is logical, that amount of accumulated liters that I expelled somewhere had to be) they could have taken the trouble to probe me before) and when I began to urinate less and less and more and more reddish (very reddish). I do not know if the test that was done before my second operation (an Rx with contrast) could have been done earlier and saved my intestine.
After the second operation, my small intestine was sectioned with the flanges (... they say for efforts) so I had to operate a third time and also cut part of the small intestine. How they could no longer sew me to close me, it was necessary to move the muscles from my back to my belly to make me like a girdle (something like that, I'm not a doctor and I can't explain myself) Later, the ileostomy scar opened when I removed the stitches prematurely. I was so, so unlucky that I even "lost" applications for insurance processing for vacuum healing treatment for open wounds with which I "left" the hospital. The health insurance assured me that he never received them. In the end another doctor from another hospital asked me for this machine and my wounds healed.
So I don't know ... my experience, to put it mildly, was not good. Now I will carry a bag for life, a completely disfigured belly and constant pain in my back.
The good thing is that you have a wonderful ICU staff, good people in patient care and a large part of the nurses who are very efficient and committed to their work.

Although the following is intended to review a Spanish hospital, I'll write it first in English then in French.

My wife and I had chosen that hospital to have the best condition for our baby to come to this world. Nevertheless the service and the lack of attention we received during our stay last week was clearly unacceptable. Almost everything (the gynaecologist was nevertheless remarkable, I can't deny it) as for me a failure.
The following questions will have to be answered by those people who claimed to be professionals:

-How could I be told to go to our room (2 floors above) and wait patiently to be called while they were supposed to prepare my wife's delivery?

-How can a delivery be exceptionally so fast that a hospital of that calibre can't manage to have both parents in the delivery room?

-How could that night's anaesthetist be so busy with another patient that he couldn't do the epidural to my wife?

-How could my wife be told at least twice they could only call her husband whenever the epidural would be done (thing which never occurred...)?

-How could a nurse tell to a midwife, asking if my wife was in pain, that she was in a rush?

-How could a mother-to-be be  in such distress (no epidural, no husband next to her, no help from the staff) be categorised as a drama queen?

I'd strongly recommend anyone to do exhaustive research about this hospital before considering anything.

My wife and I had chosen this hospital so that our baby would have the best conditions to come into the world. Nonetheless, the service and lack of attention we received during our stay last week was clearly unacceptable. Almost everything (the gynecologist was remarkable, I can't deny it) was a bitter failure for me.
People who have claimed to be professionals will need to answer the following questions:

I highly recommend anyone to thoroughly research this hospital before considering anything.

Entr√© en el hospital quiron San Jos√© la madrugada del 25 de octubre de 2018, pasada la 1h30 de la madrugada con 4cm de dilataci√≥n. Al pasar a la sala para que me pusieran la v√≠a me dejaron ah√≠ un buen rato. Mi marido avis√≥ al personal de la entrada 2 veces para que viniese alguien porque las contracciones eran muy dolorosas. Tardaron bastante.
Cuando vinieron, me bajaron al paritorio y para nuestra sorpresa a mi marido Le dijeron que subiera a la habitaci√≥n,que en cuanto me pusieran la epidural, Le llamar√≠an al tel√©fono de la habitaci√≥n y podr√≠a bajar a reunirse conmigo. Nos extra√±√≥ bastante, pero nos dijeron que el marido no pod√≠a estar presente mientras me pusieran la epidural. Por lo que yo fui sola al paritorio, donde me cambi√© como pude (nadie me ayud√≥), ya que las contracciones eran cada vez m√°s fuertes y esper√©. Tampoco vino la matrona a examinarme, cosa que tambi√©n me extra√±√≥.
Vino una enfermera a la que le pregunt√© por el anastesista. Me dijo que el anestesista estaba ocupado con otra paciente y que ten√≠a que esperar. Le ped√≠ que llamar√°n a mi marido y me dio la misma respuesta que la enfermera que me hab√≠a llevado al paritorio : "llamaremos a tu marido cuando te hayan puesto la epidural, ya que √©l no puede estar presente mientras lo hacen".
Al rato y con unas contracciones muy fuertes, volv√≠ a preguntar a la enfermera por el anastesista y por mi marido y me volvi√≥ a dar las dos mismas respuestas :¬† "el anestesista estaba ocupado con otra paciente y mi marido ten√≠a que estar en la habitaci√≥n hasta que me pusieran la epidural". Por fin o√≠ como una mujer (creo que una matrona) le preguntaba a la enfermera si ten√≠a mucho dolor y la enfermera Le contest√≥ "tiene prisa". La mujer entonces entr√≥ a ver qu√© me pasaba y me pregunt√≥ que si quer√≠a que me explorase. No entend√≠ porqu√© me preguntaba, se supone que ese es su trabajo y deber√≠a ella valorar si me explora o no. Yo Le respond√≠ que si. Consegu√≠ tumbarme de lado como pude (no recib√≠ ayuda de nadie) y me explor√≥ mientras ten√≠a medio cuerpo tumbado en la camilla y las piernas colgando. Entonces me dijo que estaba de 9cm.
Me dijo que el anestesista me podr√≠a poner una anestesia que actuase m√°s r√°pido, pero que me ten√≠a que sentar. Intent√© sentarme, pero no pude, las contracciones eran muy fuertes y nadie me ayudaba. Ya s√≥lo ten√≠a ganas de empujar. Empec√© a reclamar a gritos que llamasen a mi marido, que no hab√≠a derecho a que me tratasen as√≠ y una de las mujeres que hab√≠a ah√≠ me dijo que si quer√≠a empujar, que lo hiciese. Me di cuenta que la matrona se volv√≠a hacia el aparato que muestra la frecuencia card√≠aca del beb√© y las contracciones y vio que no estaba conectado. En ese momento empec√© a llorar y a empujar y por fin vi el rostro de la ginec√≥loga, un gran alivio ya que era la √∫nica persona que conocia en ese cuarto y la √∫nica persona que me trat√≥ como una paciente. Empatizo enseguida conmigo y tom√≥ las riendas de la situaci√≥n. Consegu√≠ tumbarme boca arriba y empujar para que mi hija empezase a salir. 4 empujones m√°s tarde ten√≠a a mi hija embrazos. Entonces apareci√≥ mi marido.
O√≠ como una de las mujeres me dec√≠a que casi dejo sin mano a la enfermera mientras empujaba, un comentario bajo mi punto de vista que se pod√≠a haber ahorrado, ya que ped√≠ en repetidas ocasiones que llamasen a mi marido y no lo hicieron.
Tuve la sensaci√≥n de que el personal de esa noche pensaba que exageraba en todo momento, ni preguntaron si necesitaba algo, ni me exploraron, ni me ayudaron en ning√∫n momento. Si no llego a quejarme tanto, doy a luz sin ni siquiera el ginec√≥logo!
Nosotros hemos escrito y enviado ya una reclamaci√≥n a la direcci√≥n general de coordinaci√≥n de la atenci√≥n al ciudadano y humanizaci√≥n de la asistencia sanitaria.

(Translated by Google)
I entered the Quiron San Jos√© hospital in the early morning of October 25, 2018, after 1:30 am with 4cm of dilation. When they went to the living room so they could put the line for me, they left me there for a long time. My husband called the entrance staff 2 times to have someone come because the contractions were so painful. They took a long time.
When they came, they took me down to the delivery room and to our surprise they told my husband to go up to the room, that as soon as they put the epidural on me, they would call him on the room phone and he could come down to meet me. We were quite surprised, but we were told that the husband could not be present while I had the epidural. So I went alone to the delivery room, where I changed as best I could (nobody helped me), since the contractions were getting stronger and I waited. Nor did the matron come to examine me, which also surprised me.
A nurse came and I asked about the anastheist. He told me that the anesthetist was busy with another patient and that he had to wait. I asked her to call my husband and she gave me the same answer as the nurse who had brought me to the delivery room: "We will call your husband when you have the epidural, since he cannot be present while they do it."
After a while and with very strong contractions, I asked the nurse again about the anasthesiologist and my husband and she gave me the same two answers: "The anesthetist was busy with another patient and my husband had to be in the room until get an epidural. " Finally I heard how a woman (I think a midwife) asked the nurse if she was in a lot of pain and the nurse replied "she's in a hurry." The woman then came in to see what was wrong with me and asked me if I wanted her to explore me. I did not understand why she was asking me, this is supposed to be her job and she should assess whether she explores me or not. I answered yes. I managed to lie on my side as best I could (I did not get help from anyone) and he explored me while I had half my body lying on the table and my legs dangling. Then he told me it was 9cm.
He told me that the anesthetist could give me a faster acting anesthesia, but that I had to sit down. I tried to sit up, but I couldn't, the contractions were very strong and no one was helping me. I just wanted to push. I began to shout to call my husband, that there was no right to treat me like that and one of the women there told me that if I wanted to push, to do it. I noticed that the midwife turned to the device that shows the baby's heart rate and contractions and saw that it was not connected. At that moment I started crying and pushing and finally saw the face of the gynecologist, a great relief since she was the only person I knew in that room and the only person who treated me like a patient. He immediately empathized with me and took charge of the situation. I managed to lie on my back and push so that my daughter started to come out. 4 pushes later I had my daughter pregnant. Then my husband appeared.
I heard one of the women tell me that she almost knocked out the nurse while pushing, a comment from my point of view that could have been saved, since I repeatedly asked them to call my husband and they did not.
